description: Maintain current condition with no intervention - baseline scenario for additionality calculations
notes: Used as comparison for all other scenarios. Zero cost and immediate effect.

description: Remove or breach dikes, restore tidal channels, reconnect historic flow patterns. Major engineering intervention.
notes: High cost due to earthworks, culverts, and monitoring. 2 years to establish stable hydrology before vegetation response.

description: Plant native salt marsh species (Salicornia, Distichlis, Carex). Includes site preparation, planting, and initial maintenance.
notes: Medium cost. Includes seedlings, labor, and 2-year maintenance. Full canopy closure by year 3.

description: Transplant eelgrass (Zostera marina) shoots or broadcast seeds. Requires suitable depth and light conditions.
notes: High cost due to underwater work and high initial mortality. Requires 4 years to establish dense meadow.

description: Control invasive species (Spartina alterniflora, Phragmites australis). Mechanical removal or targeted herbicide application.
notes: Low-medium cost. Rapid effect (1 year) but may require repeated treatments. Enables native recovery.

description: Selective thinning of forest canopy to reduce shading and promote understory vegetation. Targets areas with encroaching upland species.
notes: Low cost. Immediate effect on light availability. Promotes herbaceous layer carbon accumulation.

description: Managed livestock grazing with 6-month rest periods. Prevents woody encroachment while maintaining herbaceous productivity.
notes: Low cost (fence installation + management). Takes 2 years to establish rotation pattern and vegetation response.

description: Halt regular mowing or haying operations. Allows natural vegetation succession and soil carbon accumulation.
notes: Very low cost (just monitoring). Rapid effect - vegetation responds within one growing season.

description: Import clean sediment to raise marsh surface elevation. Enhances flood resilience and carbon burial capacity.
notes: Very high cost due to sediment sourcing and transport. Takes 3 years for vegetation to colonize new substrate.

description: Re-establish historic tidal channel networks. Improves drainage, sediment delivery, and habitat connectivity.
notes: Medium-high cost. Requires hydrological modeling and precise excavation. 2 years to stabilize.

description: Excavate and remove historic fill material to restore original grade. Allows tidal inundation and wetland vegetation.
notes: High cost due to excavation and disposal. Takes 3 years for soil processes to re-establish.

description: Remove sections of roadway or constructed berm blocking tidal flow. Partial restoration with infrastructure considerations.
notes: Very high cost due to engineering and permitting. Immediate hydrological effect but vegetation lags 2 years.

description: Create small drainage channels to improve tidal exchange in waterlogged areas. Low-impact intervention.
notes: Low-medium cost. Quick effect on drainage (1 year). Promotes aerobic soil conditions.

description: Implement practices to reduce nutrient inputs from adjacent agriculture. May include buffer strips or bioreactors.
notes: Medium cost. Indirect effect taking 3 years as water quality improves. Benefits both carbon storage and habitat.

description: Install living shorelines, coir logs, or oyster reefs to reduce wave energy and marsh edge erosion.
notes: Medium cost. Stabilizes within 2 years. Prevents carbon loss from erosion while creating habitat.

description: Aerial or manual broadcasting of native seed mixes. Low-intensity intervention for large areas.
notes: Low cost compared to transplanting. Takes 2 years for germination and establishment. Weather-dependent success.

description: Selective removal of invasive woody species to reduce competition. Less intensive than complete removal.
notes: Low-medium cost. Rapid effect (1 year). May need follow-up treatments but less disruptive than full removal.

description: Adjust water control structures to restore historic salinity regime. Critical for salt marsh recovery in impounded areas.
notes: Medium cost. Requires infrastructure modification and monitoring. Vegetation responds within 2 years of salinity shift.

description: Clean up accumulated debris (logs, wrack, trash) that smothers vegetation and prevents recruitment.
notes: Very low cost (labor only). Immediate benefit - allows light and seedling establishment in next growing season.

description: Ongoing monitoring and adaptive adjustments to restoration actions based on performance. Not a standalone action.
notes: Annual cost for monitoring and adaptive responses. Applies to any active restoration scenario. Improves long-term success.
